newsitem.title: CANADA: "Anne of Green Gables" house damaged in fire.
newsitem.headline: "Anne of Green Gables" house damaged in fire.

text.p: A fire on Friday damaged the world renowned "Anne of Green Gables" house on Prince Edward Island, a much loved tourist attraction in Atlantic Canada, authorities said.

Fire officials said the blaze broke out early on Friday and spread through the main rooms of the 19th-century farmhouse, which was the inspiration for Lucy Maud Montgomery's 1908 novel "Anne of Green Gables".

"It's a major disaster. We have extensive damage in the central portion of the house at the ground level and we have extenuating fire damage into the upper level," said Fire Marshall Dave Blacquiere. "There is smoke damage and considerable water damage throughout the building."
The cause of the fire was under investigation.
Although the exterior of the house was not damaged, the central interior and much of the house's period furniture was scorched and damaged by smoke, soot and water.
Blacquiere said his heart sank when he received the early morning alarm. He had hoped the fire would be anywhere but the Green Gables house.
"We live amongst Anne of Green Gables folklore, so when any small portion of that is taken away from us, it's hurtful," he told Reuters.
But Blacquiere said the house was structurally sound and could be restored.

Parks Canada spokeswoman Elaine Robichaud said officials expected to be able to salvage most of the artifacts and reconstruct the inside of the house. The two-storey, green-gabled house had been open for just more than a week for the summer season when it caught fire.
"We are hoping for August to get the house fully operational," said Robichaud.

Meanwhile, Parks Canada, which operates the site, will offer audio-visual presentations in a recently built addition to the site, and guided visits of the trails and surrounding landscape that inspired much of Montgomery's work.
The house, which is open from May to late October, attracts about 220,000 visitors each season from all over the world, especially Japan.
